BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna and Child
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Fra Bartolomeo, but the coarse features and the fumbling stroke make it more probable that this drawing is Albertinelli's. The late Mr. Charles Loeser, in the Uffizi publication just referred to, would ascribe this little sketch to Piero di Cosimo. Much could be adduced in favour of this attribution as the likeness in the hatching and stroke between this sketch and others by Piero is undeniable. It can, however, be accounted for by Albertinelli's having been taught drawingin Piero's studio. The round head and deep-set eyes of the Child, so much like my 1852, could be explained in the same way. But, above all, I do not remember any composition of Piero's so close in pattern and contrapposto to both Fra Bartolomeo and Raphael. It looks like a drawing done in 1505 or 1508

If, however, "Tommaso" was only a phase of Piero di Cosimo, as seems more and more likely, then he would have been Piero di cosimo's pupil all along

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Athletic nude with arms tied behind struggling to get free, but bent nearly double with the effort, the left leg pressed hard under the thigh
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: This rapid but masterly sketch, which has all the essential qualities of Michelangelo's feeling and touch, must have been meant for the figure of a slave - perhaps for the one we now see in the Victory of the Palazzo Vecchio - intended for the Tomb of Julius. The attitude suggests certain of the decorative nudes in the Sixtine Ceiling. This, among other considerations, leads up to place it between the completion of the frescoes and the commencement of the plans for the fa√ßade of S. Lorenzo. But the way of indicating the contours with curving lines which cross one another is singular, and exactly paralleled in only one other drawing, and that of the period of the Last Judgement, namely a leaf in the British Museum (my 1508), with a study among others perhaps for a scene in Dante's Purgatorio. This consideration need, however, not disturb us in assigning the sketch to an earlier date. Michelangelo's technique and stroke change little in the course of lifetime. The only "fool-proof" indication of date that I venture to name is that in no drawing earlier than the Cavalieri series does Michelangelo attempt to model with an effect of rubbing.

BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_text_verso: drapery and hands highly finished, legs slightly indicated. The head on the recto which in different positions Andrea drew more than once, probably was not made, as the Louvre catalogue states, for the Zacharias in the Scalzo Visitation, nor, as might occur to others, for one of the apostles on left in the Last Supper. It is much more likely that Andrea, whose habit it was to make almost no change from a study of a detail to its final form in the finished work, intended this head for that of the old man kneeling before Caesar in the Poggio a Caiano fresco

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of young woman
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: I am not acquainted with the original but assuming as we may on Fishel's authority that is an autograph, the sketch on the recto is of great interest. Impossible not to connect it with one of Andrea's finest achievements, the Uffizi portrait just mentioned, And yet the difference is puzzling. The sketch seems to be of a younger person and of one nearer the people than the lady in the picture, who looks mature, cultivated, and clever. dis the artist use a model with fourtuitous likeness to the lady or is the latter only the image, the "Wunschbild" -the wish fulfilment- of the other?

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: inspired perhaps by some version of the well-known antique bust of Homer. Dr. Fr√∂hlich Bum, who first published these sketches, connects the two figures with the Poggio a Caiano fresco, the draped bust with the young man next to the grey-beard who stands erect to our right of the same composition. These last have nothing in common but the action, which is not surprising seeing that this part of the fresco was finished by Allori. The heads have a certain likeness to this or that in his works of about 1520 but identity with none.

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_text_recto: [1959: Malgrado la tradizionale attribuzione ad Andrea del Sarto, il giovane sul recto √® cos√¨ simile ai disegni del Pontormo intorno al 1530, che io lo assegnai all'allievo di Andrea, e proposi che potesse essere uno studio per il Pigmalione dei Barberini. Per√≤ John Shearman (Burlington Magazine, Aprile 1959), riferisce il foglio all'"Assunta Passerini" (Pitti n. 225), alla quale Andrea del Sarto lavorava intorno al 1526: egli vede nel recto uno studio per la Santa Margherita da Cortona, genuflessa in primo piano, e nel

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Its precise destination is not clear. Even as a drawing the same head with slight variations recurs, as for instance in the Louvre. BB_1961_verso.BB_1961_title_verso: Due registrazioni di pagamenti scritti di mano di Michelangelo

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies, in reversed order, for the Madonna and Child. In the one she is seen full face, while the Child looks away to the left in the order, almost the whole figure is given, seated, looking in profile to right at the Child
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Both, particularly the one in profile, are curiously Donatellesque. These are simple drawings in pen and ink, done by Michelangelo to serve as models for Antonio Mini. Beside them we see the latter's attempts to copy them in red chalk. As he took service in December, 1523, and the date October 4, 1524, occurs on the back, it cannot be said that in the course of a year he had made great progress. His copies resemble certain primitive types of draughtsmanship - Aztec, let usa say. Michelangelo seems to have found his apprentice dawdling, and under his more wretched copy has written: "Disegnia Antonio /disegnia Antonio disegnia e no(n) p(er)der te(m)po"

BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_title_verso: Two records of payment written in Michelangelo's hand

BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_title_verso: Torso of erect figure with shoulder and beginning of arms suggesting the possibility of it's being connected with the Haman

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per le Tombe Medicee: progetto di sistemazione parietale per una doppia tomba, con due sarcofagi, contenenti figure adagiate nei coperchi concavi, di dignit√† fluviali inserite sotto i sarcofagi, una statua colossale in mezzo ad esso e uno sfondo che mostra incertezze e pentimenti. In alto, in direzione opposta, schizzo per la statua del Crepuscolo, quasi identico al marmo

BB_1961_verso.BB_1961_title_verso: Studi per le Tombe Medicee: costruzione alta e stretta consistente, dal basso in alto, in un sarcofago a coperchio piatto, due nudi in piedi, appoggiati a un grande piedistallo quadrato, che fa da base a una nicchia, fiancheggiata da scomparti minori, con ghirlande; in direzione opposta, leggere indicazioni di un progetto con due sarcofagi, dal coperchio triangolare; perpendicolarmente ai due studi precedenti, un terzo progetto con un sarcofago dal coperchio a lunetta

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Medici Tombs. Certainly from Michelangelo's own hand, as the touch, the stroke, and the peculiar "shorthand" clearly prove. Two sarcophagi stand alongside. The cover of each, consisting of two shallow concave curves, supports a reclining figure. Under the sarcophagus on the left lies a river god. Between the sarcophagi on a pedestal a colossal figure stands erect against the wall. To right and left are windows or rather rectangular niches resting on supports. The one to the right is more elaborated. In the niche itself is the indication of a herma, and against its supports lean two nudes in smaller proportions than the other figure. The the wall forming this background was meant to have a certain thickness, and the monument a certain depth, may be inferred from the indication of figures at the sides. At the top of the sheet, but turned round, is a slight but clear sketch for the Twilight nearly as it was afterwards completed
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Not only the plan, but, as well, the sketch going with it on the back, suggests a monument to stand free with four sides. But the more elaborated study on the front must have been made after that idea was given up, for the notion of two sarcophagi side by side was obviously not to be entertained in connection with a monument to stand in the middle of the sacristy. On the other hand, we are not forced to assume that the sketch for the Twilight necessarily implies that this sheet belongs to an advanced period of Michelangelo's labour over this monument. He may well have had the single figures clearly in mind from the very beginning. It was probably not these which gave him trouble, but the architectural and decorative design. Here the arrangement is still far from what finally was adopted. The likeness of the figures to those which probably existed in the scheme for the Tomb of Julius should be noted. It is interesting also to see how Michelangelo first intended to place the river gods.

BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_title_verso: Sketch containing a sarcophagus, and above it a large pedestal with two figures leaning against it, and over it a window or rather niche. This, although it may be simply a study for one half of the monument on the other side, seems more probably a sketch for the four-square monument. Also ground-plan of a square with a sarcophagus on one of its sides

To right a youthful nude seated on cloth which drapes his right leg only, his right arm held up and his left grasping the cloth
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Meticulous and dainty, this sketch betrays in the nude figure the inspiration of Fra Angelico and the young Benozzo. The draped study is as close to Masaccio. As the only painter of note who imitated all those masters just mentioned was Andrea di Giusto, we may propose him as the author of this drawing. But for the Masacciesque aposle, one would be tempted to ascribe it to youthful Benozzo.

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: St. Matthew
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: In the text to this publication, A.M. Hind gives an exhaustive account of this sheet, and correctly relates it to the figure of the Evangelist in the ceiling of the Vatican chapel erected by Nicholas V. He pleads that we should accept both sides as autographs by Fra Angelico. These is little trouble in agreeing with him about the Luke, which is ample, free, and natural. Indeed the head reminds one of an abvious portrait in the Stoning of Stephen in the same chapel, and the difference between the crafts would account for the interesting divergence between the freedom of the drawing and the relative tighness of the painted figure. The sketch of thr Matthew, on the other hand, is stiffer, flatter, more stilted than in the fresco, and the draperies take on a more angular twist. For these reasons this side of the sheet may be assigned to Benozzo while working under Fra Angelico.

BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_title_verso: St. Luke.

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_title_recto: Studio architettonico per le Tombe Medicee, macchiato e confuso, ma forse il pi√π interessante di tutti gli schizzi superstiti e certamente autografo: √® un progetto di tomba parietale con un solo sarcofago su cui si adagiano due figure che ricordano l'Aurora e il Crepuscolo: le loro teste toccano la cornice sulla quale si ergono scomparti dello sfondo, uno quadrato al centro, due rettangolari ai lati, divisi da coppie di colonne o pilastri considerevolmente aggettanti la suddivisione continua nel fastoso coronamento con troni sopra le coppie di colonne, che separano la ricca panoplia al centro degli scomparti laterali, con figure accovacciate sotto ghirlande nel riquadro a sinistra del sarcofago √® schizzata la figura seduta del Duca Giuliano, mentre in primo piano, sulla piattaforma in basso, giacciono due divinit√† fluviali

BB_1961_verso.BB_1961_title_verso: Due urne e contorni di un nudo che si tocca la spalla alzando il braccio destro (a carboncino)e dieci righe di un madrigale (a penna)

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Study, blurred and blotted, but perhaps the most interesting of all the sketches for the Medici Tombs, and certainly from Michelangelo's own hand. On a pedestal rests a sarcophagus with two figures, recalling the Dawn and Twilight, reclining upon it. The heads of these figures are on a level with the top of the base, the one in the middle being a square, and the others flanking it as windows. Between each two divisions are two columns or pilasters projecting considerably. Above this order are three further divisions, decorated in high relief, the one in the middle with trophies, the one n the left with crouching figures. The top was to have been highly ornate. Below, on the platform, clear of the sarcophagus, lie two river gods. Against the left-hand division of the base we see the seated figure of Duke Giuliano
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: The resemblance of this sketch to the monument as finally left is so striking that one feels tempted to believe that this is one of the last drawings that Michelangelo made for the Tombs. But there are difficulties in the way of this idea. The greatest of these is the indication, to one side, of Giuliano. Lorenzo is not drawn, but we scarcely can conceive of Giuliano thus subordinately placed to one side, unless Lorenzo was to balance him on the other. Then if this was a monument to both the dukes, how is it that there is but one sarcophagus? There is moreover, no trace in contemporary records of a deliberate intention to break with the plan established toward the end of 1523 of having the sarcophagi in pairs. If it could, however, be assumed that this drawing was later, as one is certainly tempted to assume, then it would clearly witness to Michelangelo's final decision to have the arrangement pretty much what it is now. What alternative to suggest I scarcely know. Surely not that it is a sketch for the four-sided monument as first planned

BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_title_verso: Two urns, and outlines for a nude doubling his right arm up to his chin
BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_text_verso: The nude may have had some connection with the Victory of the Palazzo Vecchio. Should that have been the case, then Michelangelo must have been working on this group while the plans for the Tombs were being settled. Also a number of lines of a madrigal published in Frey's Dichtungen, p. 15. A drawing clearly resembling the recto may have been known to the sculptor of the beautiful monument to a Duke of Montmorency (died 1652) at Moulins, translated of course in the severe forms of the most noble 17th century in France.

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Design for podium of Tomb of Julius, made probably in 1526
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Under the design is the following in the artist's own hand: Questo schizo e una parte della faccia dina(n)zi della sepultura el quale e tucto / finito di quadro e d intagli la qual parte e alta dalla terra alla prima corni / ce braccia sei e dall u(n) canto all altro di largeza braccia u(n)dici ed e di pezi / sessa(n)ta secte cho(n) que pezi segniati ch(e) u e su el numero. ed e messo i(n) / sieme in una sta(n)za che e in casa i(n) sul cortile nella quale / sta(n)za e dua ruote d u(n) carra ch(e) io feci fare e lasso el resto e / in un altra sta(n)za terrena i(n) casa i(n) roma."

Per altre copie di questa composizione vedi Wilde.]

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a composition of Christ's Resurrection
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: The most carefully thought-out and noblest of the designs for this subject. Here Christ floats away as in a dream, like a rising mist, and even the soldiers have less agitated attitudes. The greatest merit of this composition is, perhaps, its spaciousness and the pictorial intention is, for Michelangelo, singularly clear. If Sebastiano had put painted it, we should have had a picture of a solemnity and grandeur rivalling, if not surpassing, his matchless Piet√†. The forms and the technique have all the characteristics of the Cavalieri and kindred drawings, and the date is therefore about 1533.

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_title_recto: Un foglio di una cronaca figurata

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Di esse, sette si trovavano a Haarlem, nella Raccolta Koenigs nel 1937: alla dispersione della Raccolta, due furono acquistate dal Fogg Art Museum e la destinazione delle altre cinque mi √® ignota.

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Presentation in the Temple, Christ before Pilate and Crucifixion
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Three highly finished miniature compositions. Unacquainted with the originals, I can say no more than this: If these miniatures are of the 15th century they may be careful copies by an Umbrian, perhaps Caporali after a series of panels by Fra Angelico, not identical with any known at present but which may have existed and probably in Umbria. The same miniatures appeared at the Mensing Sale, Amsterdam, July, 1927, and are reproduced in catalogue as n. 249 along with a Christ among the Doctors, a Washing of Feet, which, however, may be, as the catalogue says, by a stiffer and it seems to me more Florentine hand. Text of same catalogue says there were ten of these miniatures in 18th century binding with royal crest. (As far as I know there are seven in the Koenigs Collection at present - 1937).

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per le Tombe Medicee, con due sarcofagi affiancati posti davanti a una parete articolata in tre scomparti quadrati inferiori e tre scomparti allungati superiori nell'ordine superiore, il tabernacolo centrale sormontato da una lunetta, contiene una statua seduta e i tabernacoli laterali, sormontati da occhi, contengono figure in piedi nell'ordine inferiore, il riquadro centrale contiene il leggerissimo schizzo della Fama, seduta a braccia spalancate, che tocca le lapidi infestonate nei riquadri laterali in basso si legge, di mano di Michelangelo: "La fama tiene gli epitafi a giacere / Non va n√© innanzi n√© indietro, / Perch√© son morti e e' loro operare √® fermo"

BB_1961_verso.BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per le Tombe Medicee, eguale a quello sul recto nelle linee fondamentali, ma meno lavorato e con la differenza che i riquadri inferiori contengono, invece delle lapidi, statue sedute in posizioni alquanto simili a quelle delle attuali statue dei Duchi. Manca la figura della Fama; mancano le figure nei tabernacoli laterali superiori e la statua seduta nel tabernacolo centrale √® sostituita da una vaga figura allungata

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Medici Tombs. Two sarcophagi on a platform against a high background, consisting of a base in three divisions, and above it a high windowlike opening flanked by a niche on each side. In this opening appears a tall seated figure, and in each niche the indication of a standing one. At the bottom of the sheet is an inscription, not divided into lines, which I copy out of Prof. Frey's invaluable edition of Michelangelo's verse: "La fame tiene gli epitafi a giacere, / Non va n√© inanzi n√© indietro, / Perch√© son morti, e e' loro operare fermo."
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: This sheet, from Michelangelo's own hand, is a further study for the arrangement of the Tombs in pairs along the walls of the Sacristy. The sketch on the back is clearly for the monument of the two dukes. The destination of the other is less certain. I state as a mere possibility that it was for the monument to Lorenzo the Magnificent and his brother Giuliano, in which case the seated figure would represent the Madonna which is now placed over their tombs.

BB_1938_verso.BB_1938_title_verso: Two sarcophagi of the simplest possible kind, standing on a high platform against a wall in six divisions, the three below shorter, and forming a kind of base. In the upper middle division a scrawl to indicate the figure. Just above each sarcophagus a seated figure, and, I mistake not, the one at the right is Lorenzo, and the other Giuliano, in something like the attitudes that they now have

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Study in tiny figures of Procession to Calvary starting from town gate and winding up escarped terraces to Golgotha, where the Crucifixion takes place
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Spirited sketch closer perhaps to Baldovinetti than to any other known artist, but at the same time suggesting Antonio Pollaiuolo and even the youthful Botticelli. Interesting to compare this with Jacopo Bellini's drawings. The difference between Florence and Venice in the middle decades of the Quattrocento could scarcely be better exemplified. a kindred composition but on a lower level of artistic quality used by the engraver of Baldovinetti.

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_title_recto: Semplici contorni, buttati gi√π alla svelta, di due aspetti di una figura inginocchiata nella posa della "Madonna Doni", ma con le braccia nella posizione tenuta dall'Eterno nella "Separazione della luce dalle tenebre" sulla volta della Cappella Sistina. Le teste sono appena accennate le misure in braccia sono annotate in diversi punti

BB_1961_verso.BB_1961_title_verso: Linee di scrittura

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Mere outlines, rapidly jotted down, of two aspects of a figure kneeling in the attitude of the Doni Madonna, but with the arms in the position held by the Eternal in the separation of Light from Darkness in Sixtine Ceiling. The heads are barely indicated. Measurements in braccia are noted down at various points
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Meder (Handz., p. 364, fig. 139) and Popp (M.K., p. 146) have noticed that these sketches are not, ad I thought, for two different statues, but for one seen in two different ways, once frontally and once in profile. This scrawl gains value from its obvious intention. Evidently it was one of the many sketches sent to the stonecutters at Carrara or Seravezza to guide them in blocking out the figures quarried at Michelangelo's orders. Of such drawings there is frequent mention in the contracts and correspondence between the artist and the workmen. It would be of high interest to discover which statue was to be fashioned out of the marble to be thus rough hewn. I have looked through the contracts and letters between Michelangelo and the stonecutters in the hope of finding a correspondence between the measurements in the drawing and any of those given there but in this again I have had no success. Popp (M. K., pp. 145-46) fancies that it may have been for the river gods and of later date. My impression is that this sketch should be dated about 1520. Before leaving it, just a word more. Here we have a drawing which was done with as much unconsciousness of aesthetic intention as is the writing itself. Yet its quality as touch, even as expression of function, is of the highest. I would have this brought to the attention of writers who attribute to Michelangelo such idiot-drawings as the one in the Uffizi for the Tomb of Julius, on the ground that in work of this nature there was no aesthetic intention, and that therefore its puerility does not exclude its being from Michelangelo's own hand. Now correct draughtsmanship may doubtless have much to do with the artist's intention but the quality of touch, the life, the sparkle, the vibration have just as much to do with his intention as the shape of his head or the colour of his eyes. The age of discretion once attained, and dotage not yet reached, the great draughtsman cannot, if he would, draw lifelessly.

BB_1903_recto.BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: But while the reclining figure might conceivably represent one at S. Lorenzo, the other has no relation to any statue of which I have been able to discover record. (‚Ä¶) A more diligent and intelligent research might however meet with the proper reward.

It now seems probable that it was dane by Alunno in one of his more eclectic and less happy moments. The draperies are his, and Jerome's eye is unmistakable

BB_1903_recto.BB_1903_text_recto: The types are clearly those of a follower of Rosselli - the Child goes even back to Rosselli's master Baldovinetti - but the feeble author of this drawing betrays the influence of Piero as well, and the remote effect of Botticelli also. He must have been a painter of the character of those who have left more than one picture on the altars of S. Spirito

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Elaborate composition for Conversion of Paul
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Whatever qualities this may have as drawing have disappeared under the pricking of the outlines. I used to ascribe to Piero di cosimo this design inspired no doubt by the earlier Florentine engraving reproduced on p. 14 of Colvin's Maso Finiguerra, but landscape apart I no longer see justification for this attribution. The types and the action both have the character intermediate between Ghirlandaio and Botticelli which mark Alunno. One is the more disposed to assign it to him as it served for the famous plate engraved by Matteo di Giovanni Dei in the Bargello. A niello print of it till recently in Paul Kristeller's Collection is reproduced on p. 20 of Knoedler's Engravings and Etchings for 1931. Alunno, as I have long ago insisted, made a business of furnishing drawings to the engravers. i am indebted to Mr. John Walker for pointing out the connection between this Conversion and the Bargello plate

BB_1903_recto.BB_1903_text_recto: Whatever qualities this may have had as drawing have disappeared under the pricking of the outlines. It may, however, have been Piero's.

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Joachim and Anna clasp hands in front of a niche
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: Pricked for transfer. I owe my acquaintance with this drawing to Mr. Byam Shaw. It is attributed to Perugino and is inscribed by a later hand on the cornices of the pillars with the words "Raffaello del Garbo" for no other reason, probably, than that Baldinucci or whoever it was who inscribed it with these words supposed that all Florentine cartoons for embroideries of about 1500 were made by Garbo.

BB_1961_recto.BB_1961_title_recto: Epifania

BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Adoration of Magi
BB_1938_recto.BB_1938_text_recto: In the first edition I catalogued this delighful sketch as David Ghirlandaio's, saying that if his it was his finest pen-drawing. Not many years later I began to feel that it was at once too Botticellian and too Peruginesque, for David. The type as well as the folds of the Virgin are distinctly Peruginesque, the second king is all but a copy of Sandro, and the standing figures behind are Botticellian. The combination of elements pointed to Alunno. Looking closer I perceived that the faces and the draperies were certainly his. Later still I realized that his drawing must have served for the fresco in Sala V, "dei Misteri" of the Borgia Apartments. Francovich arrived at the same coclusion independently. So did my friend John Walker. The differences between the sketch and the painting are interesting. It would seem as if Pintoricchio found that the design was too Florentine and insisted on bringing the fresco into closer harmony with his own style. The effort accounts for the inferiority of the finished work

BB_1903_recto.BB_1903_text_recto: The general Ghirlandaiesque character of this drawing is manifest, but for Domenico it is too feeble in handling, and, in one or two of the figures on the right, too flagrantly Leonardesque. David, on the other hand, was not shy of copying Leonardo, and nearer the arch one or more heads with wedge-like faces are almost as good as his, David's signature. If his, as I believe, this is his finest pen drawing.
